I'll take my lean, gallants God buoy all.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: God buoy m. Vaux, I was ye ha' lost good guests.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You shall be my guest for a night or two,
Cousin, till your own lodging be prepared,
But tell me sir what means hath m. Fludde.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I'll ask him if ye will.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Do so, and if his fortunes be debased,
I'll entertain him if he'll dwell with me,
On good condition.

sp.speaker: Stran. M.
sp.l: Mathew Fludde,
He are ye my cousin Brackenbury's mind?
He hath conceived such liking of your parts,
that if your means surmount not his suppose,
He'll entertain ye gladly at the tower,
To wait on him, and put ye in great trust.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: In what I undertake I will be just,
And hold me happy, if my diligence
May please so worthy a gentleman as he,
Whate'er my fortunes have been, they are now,
Such as to service make their master bow.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No flood more like a friend and fellow mate,
I mean to use thee, than a servitor,
And place thee in some credit in the tower,
And give thee means to live in some good sort.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I thank ye sir, God grant I may deserve it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Cousin and all your crew come home with me,
Where after sorrow we may merry be.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: The tower will be a place of secret rest,
Where I may hear good news and bad, and use the best,
God bless the King, a worse may wear the crown
And then Jane Shore thy credit will come down,
For though I'll never bed nor board with thee,
Yet thy destruction with I not to see,
Because I loved thee when thou wast my wife,
Not for now saving my disdained life,
Which lasts too long. God grant us both to mend,
Well I must in my service to attend.

div.stage: The lord Lovell and doctor Shaw meet on the stage.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Well met my good lord Lovell.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Whither away so fast goes doctor Shaw?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why to the tower, to shrive the Duke of Clarence,
Who as I hear is fallen so grievous sick,
As it is thought be can by no means scape.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He neither can nor shall I warrant thee:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I hope my lord he is not dead already?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But I hope sir he is, I am sure I saw him dead,
of a fly's death, drowned in a butt of malmsey.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Drowned in a butt of malmsey? that is strange,
Doubtless he never would misdo himself?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: No, that thou knowest right well, he had some helpers,
Thy hand was in it with the Duke of Gloucester's,
As smoothly as thou seekst to cover it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O foul words my lord, no more of that,
The world knows nothing, then what should I fear?
Doth not your honour seek promotion?
O give the doctor then a little leave,
So that he gain preferment with a King,
Cares not who goes to wrack, whose heart doth wring.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A King? what King?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why Richard man? who else? good lord I see,
Wise men sometimes have weak capacity.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why is not Edward living? and if he were not,
Hath be not children? what shall become of them?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why man, lining for beds, a knife, or so,
What make a boy a King, and a man by,
Richard, a man for us? fie that were a shame.
Nay then I see if Edward were deceased,
Which way the game would go.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: What else my lord?
That way the current of our fortune runs,
By noble Richard gallant royal Richard,
He is the man must only do us good,
So I have honour, let me swim through blood.
My lord, be but at Paul's cross on Sunday next,
I hope I have it here shall soundly prove,
King Edward's children not legitimate.
Nay, and that for Edward ruling now,
And George the Duke of Clarence so late dead:
Their mother happed to tread the shoe awry,
Why what is Richard then?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Tut, lawful man, he says it so himself.
And what he says I'll be so hold to swear,
though in my soul I know it otherwise,
Beware promotion while you live my lord.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A staff, a staff, a thousand crowns for a staff.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What staff sir William Catesby?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why man a white staff for my lord protector.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why is King Edward dead?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Dead Lovel, dead, and Richard our good lord
Is made protector of the sweet young prince.
O for a staff, where might I have a staff,
That I might first present it to his hand?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Now do I smell two bishoprics at least,
My sermon shall be peppered sound for this.

div.stage: Enter mistress Shoare weeping, jockey following.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why how now mistress Shore? what, put finger in the ease,
Nay then I see you have some cause to cry.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I blame her not, her chiefest stay is gone,
The only staff, she had to lean upon,
I see by her these tidings are too true.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I my lord Lovell, they are too true indeed,
Royal King Edward now hath breathed his last,
The Queen turned out, and every friend put by,
None now admitted, but whom Richard please.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why doubtless Richard will be kind to you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Ah my lord Lovell, God bless me from his kindness:
No sooner was the white staff in his hand,
But finding me and the right woeful Queen,
Sadly bemoaning such a mighty loss:
Here is no place quoth he, you must be gone,
We have other matters now to think upon.
For you, (Quoth he to me) ant bit his lip,
And stroke me with his staff, but said no more.
Whereby I know he meaneth me no good.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Well mistress Shore, it's like to be a busy time,
Shift for yourself, come lads let us be gone,
Royal King Richard must be wait upon.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Well mistress Shore, if you have need of me,
You shall command me to the uttermost.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: First let me die ere I do put my trust,
In any fliering spaniel of you all.
Go jockey, take down all my hangings,
And quickly see my trunks be conveyed forth,
To mistress Blages, an inn in Lombardstreet,
The flower de Luce, good jockey make some speed,
She, she must be my refuge in this need.
See it done quickly jockey.

sp.speaker: Jockey.
sp.p: Whickly quoth 'a? marry here's a whick change indeed, sike whick change did I ne'er see before. Now dream I, that Ise be a very pure fellow, and hardly ha any siller to drink with a good fellow. But what stand I tattling here. I must go do my masters bidding, carry all her stuff and gear to mistress Blages, at the flower de luce in Lombardstreet, whick then dispatch.

div.stage: Enter Brackenbury, and flood, to them the two young princes, Edward and Richard, Gloster, Cates. Lovell and Tirill.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come hither flood let me hear thy opinion,
Thou knowest I build upon thy confidence,
And honest dealing in thy greatest affairs:
I have received letters from the Duke,
Gloster I mean, protector of the land,
Who gives in charge the tower be prepared,
This night to entertain the two young princes,
It is my duty to obey I know,
but manifold suspicion troubles me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He is their uncle sir, and in that sense,
Nature should warrant their security,
Next his deceased brother at his death,
To Richard's care committed both the realm,
And their protection: where humanity
Stands as an orator to plead against
All wrong suggestion of uncivil thoughts:
Beside you are lieutenant of the tower,
Say there should be any hurt pretended,
The privilege of your authority
Pries into every corner of this house,
And what can then be done without your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Thou sayest true flood, though Richard be protector,
When once they are within the tower limits,
The charge of them (Unless he derogate)
From this my office, which was never siene,
In any King's time; doth belong to me:
And ere that Brackenbury will consent,
Or suffer wrong be done unto these babes,
His sword, and all the strength within the tower
Shall be opposed against the proudest comer,
Be it to my soul as I intend to them.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: And faith in me unto this commonwealth,
And truth to men hath hitherto been seen,
The pilot that hath guided my life's course,
Though 'twas my fortune to be wronged in both:
And therefore sir neither the mighties frown,
Nor any bribes shall win me otherwise.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Tis well resolved: still methinks they should
Be safe enough with us, and yet I fear,
But now no more, it seems they are at hand.

sp.speaker: Pr. Ed.
sp.l: Uncle, what gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: It is (Sweet prince) lieutenant of the tower.

sp.speaker: Pr. Ed.
sp.l: Sir we are come to be your guests tonight :
I pray you tell me did you ever know,
our father Edward lodged within this place,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Never to lodge (My liege) but oftentimes,
On other occasions I have seen him here.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Brother last night when you did send for me
My mother told me, hearing we should lodge
Within the tower, that it was a prison,
And therefore marvelled that my uncle Gloster,
Of all the houses for a King's receipt,
Within this city, had appointed none,
Where you might keep your court but only here.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Vile brats, how they do descant on the tower.
〈◊〉 gentle nephew they were ill abused,
To tutor you with such unfitting terms,
(Who ere they were) against this royal mansion:
What if some part of it hath been reserved,
To be a prison for nobility?
Follows it therefore that it cannot serve,
To any other use? Cesar himself
That built the same, within it kept his court,
And many Kings since him, the rooms are large,
The building stately, and for strength beside,
It is the safest and the surest hold you have.

sp.speaker: Pr. Ed.
sp.l: Uncle of Gloster, if you think it so,
'Tis not for me to contradict your will,
We must allow it, and are well content.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: On then a god's name.

sp.speaker: Pr. Ed.
sp.l: Yet before we go,
One question more with you m. lieutenant,
We like you well, and but we do perceive,
More comfort in your looks, then in these walls,
For all our uncle Gloucester's friendly speech,
Our hearts would be as heavy still as lead,
I pray you tell me, at which door or gate
Was it my uncle Clarence did go in,
When he was sent a prisoner to this place?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: At this my liege: why sighs your majesty?

sp.speaker: Pr. Ed.
sp.l: He went in here that ne'er came back again,
But as God hath decreed, so let it be,
Come brother shall we go?

sp.speaker: Fish.
sp.l: Yes brother, anywhere with you.

div.stage: Tirill pulls Catesby by the sleeve.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Sir were it best I did attend the Duke,
Or stay his leisure till his back return?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I pray master Tirill stay without,
It is not good you should be seen by day
Within the tower, especially at this time,
I'll tell his honour of your being here,
And you shall know his pleasure presently.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Even so sir men: would be glad by any means.
To raise themselves, that have been overthrown,
By fortune's scorn, and I am one of them.
Here comes the Duke.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Catesby, is this the man?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: It is if't like your excellency.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Come near.
Thy name I hear is Tirill, is it not?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: James Tirill is my name, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Welcome, it should appear that thou hast been
In better state than now it seems thou art.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: I have been by my faith my lord, though now depressed,
And clouded over with adversity.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Be ruled by me, and then thou shalt rise again,
And prove more happy than thou ever wast,
There is but only two degrees by which
It shall be needful for thee to ascend,
And that is faith and taciturnity.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: If ever I prove false unto your grace,
Convert your favour to afflictions.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But canst thou too be secret?

sp.speaker: Tiril.
sp.l: Try me my lord:
This tongue was never known to be a blab.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thy countenance hath like a silver key,
Opened the closet of my heart, read there,
If scholar like thou canst expound those lines,
Thou art the man ordained to serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: So far as my capacity will reach,
The sense my lord is this, this night you say,
The two young princes both must suffer death.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Thou hast my meaning, wilt thou do it, speak?

sp.speaker: Tiril.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Enough, come follow me,
For thy direction, and for gold to fee,
Such as must aid thee in their tragedy.

div.stage: Enter mistress Blage and jockey laden.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Welcome good jockey, what good news bring you?

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Marry masters my good masters greets ye masters, and prays ye masters till dight up her chamber, for she'll lig we ye tonight masters. And here's her cat skin till she come.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Why how now loiterer? make ye no more haste?
When will my trunks and all my stuff be brought,
If you thus loiter, go, make haste withal.

sp.speaker: Jockey.
sp.l: Marry sall aye, gin you'll be bud patient a while.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Now gentle mistress Blage the only friend,
That fortune leaves me to rely upon,
My counsel's closet and my tower of strength,
To whom for safety I retire myself,
To be secure in these tempestuous times,
Oh smile on me, and give me gentle looks,
If I be welcome, then with cheerful heart,
And willing hand show me true signs thereof.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Doubt ye of welcome lady to your friend?
Nay to your servant, to your beadswoman,
To speak but truth, your bounty's bond woman:
use me, command me, call my house your own,
And all I have sweet lady at your will.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: A way with titles, lay by courtly terms,
The case is altered now the King is dead,
And with his life my fauouring friends are fled,
No madam now, but as I was before,
Your faithful kind companion, poor Jane Shore.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I loud you then, and since, and ever shall,
You are the woman, though your fortunes fall,
You when my husband's lewd transgression
Of all our wealth had lost possession,
By forfeiture into his highness' hands,
Got restitution of our goods and lands,
He fled, and died in France, to heal that harm,
You helped me to three manors in fee farm,
The worst of which clears threescore pound a year,
Have I not reason then to hold ye dear?
Yes hap what will until my life do end,
You are and shall be my best beloved friend,

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: How if misfortune my folly do succeed.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Trust me true friends bide touch in time of need.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: If want consume the wealth I had before.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: My wealth is yours, and you shall spend my store.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: But the protector prosecutes his hate.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: With me live secret from the world's debates

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: You will be weary of so bad a guest.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then let me never on the earth be blessed.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Ah mistress Blage, you tender me such love,
As all my sorrows from my soul remove,
And though my portion be not very large,
Yet come I not to you to be a charge,
Coin, plate, and fuels prized at lowest rate,
I bring with me to maintain my estate,
Worth twenty thousand pound, and my array,
If you survive to see my dying day,
From you no penny will I give away.

sp.speaker: Blage.
sp.l: And I thank you that so my wealth increased,
Am worth I trow, ten thousand pounds at least,
I think like two warm widows we may live,
Until good fortune two good husbands give,
For surely mistress Shore your husband's dead,
When heard ye of him?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Never since he fled.
O mistress Blage, now put you in my head
That kills my heart, why should I breathe this air,
Whose lost good name no treasure can repair?
O were he here with me to lead his life,
Although he never used me as a wife,
But as a drudge to spurn me with his feet,
Yet should I think with him that life were sweet,

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: How can ye once conceit so base a thing,
That have been kissed and cokerd by a King,
Weep not, you hurt yourself by gods blessed mother,
Your husband's dead woman, think upon another,
Let us in to supper, drink wine, cheer your heart,
And whilst I live, be sure I'll take your part.

div.stage: Enter Brakenburie, Shoare, Dighton, Forrest, Tirill.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Sir I assure ou 'tis my lord protectors warrant.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My friend, I have conferred it with his letters,
And 'tis his hand indeed, I'll not deny,
But blame me not although I be precise,
In matters that so nearly do concern me.

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: My lord protector, sir I make no doubt,
Dare justify his warrant, though perhaps,
He doth not now acquaint you why he doth it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I think sic there's no subject now in England,
Will urge his grace, to show what he dare do,
Nor will I ask him why he does it,
I would I might, to rid me of my doubt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Why sir I think he needs no precedent,
for what he does, I think his power is absolute enough.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have no power sir to examine it.
Nor will I do: obey your warrant,
Which I will keep for my security.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: You shall do well in that sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here's the keys.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: And yet I could wish my lord protector,
Had sent his warrant thither by some other, aside.
I do not like their looks I tell you true.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Nor I flood I assure thee.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: What does that slave mutter to his master?

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: I hear him say he does not like our looks?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Why not our looks sir?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Sirrah we hear you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I am glad you do sir? all is one for that,
But if you did not hearken better now,
I never saw three faces in whose looks,
Did ever sit more terror: or more death,
God bless the princes if it be his will,
I do not like these villains.

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: Zounds stab the villain, sirrah do you brave us?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I that's your coming, for you come to stab.

sp.speaker: Forrest.
sp.l: Stab him.

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Nay then I'll stab with thee.

sp.speaker: Tirill.
sp.l: 'Zblood cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Braken.
sp.l: Hold gentle men I pray you.

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Sir I am hurt, stabbed in the arm,

sp.speaker: Braken.
sp.l: This is not to be justified my friends, I
To draw your weapons here within the tower,
And by the law it is no less than death,
I cannot think the Duke will like of this,
I pray ye be content, too much is done.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: He might have held his peace then, and been quiet farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Hell and damnation follow murderers.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Go flood get thee some surgeon to look to thy wound.
Hast no acquaintance with some skilful surgeon?
Keep thy wound close, and let it not take air.
And for my own part, I will not stay here.
Whither wilt thou go that I may send to thee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: To one mistress Blages, an inn in gracious street,
There you shall find me, or shall hear of me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sweet princely babes, farewell I fear you sore,
I doubt these eyes shall never see you more.

div.stage: Enter the two young princes, Edward and Richard in their gowns and caps unbuttoned, and untrust.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: How does your lordship?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Well good brother Richard, how does yourselves
You told me your head-ached.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.p: Indeed it does, my lord feel with your hands how hot it is.

div.stage: He lays his hand on his brother's head.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Indeed you have caught cold,
With sitting yesternight to hear me read,
I pray thee go to bed, sweet Dick, poor little heart.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to wait upon your lordship.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I had more need brother to wait on you:
For you are sick, and so am not I.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: O lord, methinks this going to our bed,
How like it is to going to our grave:

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I pray thee do not speak of graves sweet heart,
Indeed thou frightest me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Why my lord brother, did not our tutor teach us,
That when at night we want unto our bed,
We still should think we sent unto our grave.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes that's true, that we should do as every christian ought.
To be prepared to die at every hour, but I am heavy.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Indeed and so am I.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Then let us say our prayers and go to bed.

div.stage: They kneel, and solemn music the while within, the music ceaseth, and they rise.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: What, bleeds your grace?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I two drops and no more.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: God bless us both, and I desire no more,

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Brother see here what David says, and so say I
Lord in thee will I trust although I die.

div.stage: As the young princes go out, enter Tirill.

sp.speaker: Tirill.
sp.l: Go lay ye down, but never more to rise,
I have put my hand into the foulest murder,
That ever was committed since the world,
The very senseless stones here in the walls,
Break out in tears but to behold the fact,
Methinks the bodies lying dead in graves,
Should rise and cry against us oh hark, hark,
The mandrake's shrieks are music to their cries,
The very night is frighted, and the stars,
Do drop like torches, to behold this deed:
The very centre of the earth doth shake,
Methinks the tower should rent down from the top,
To let the heaven look on this monstrous deed.

div.stage: Enter at the one door Dighton, with Edward under his arm, at the other door, Forrest with Richard.

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: Stand further damned rogue, and come not near me.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: Nay stand thou further villain, stand aside.

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: Are we not both damned for this cursed deed?

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: Thou art the witness that thou bearest the King

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: And what hearst thou?

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: It is too true, o I am damned indeed,

div.stage: He lookes down on the boy under his arm.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: I am as deep as you, although my hand
Did not the deed.

sp.speaker: Digh.
sp.l: O villain, art thou there?

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.l: A plague light on thee.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Curse not, a thousand plagues will light upon us all.
The priest here in the tower will bury them,
Let us away.

div.stage: Enter mistress Blage and her two men, bringing in Shoare alias flood, in a chair, his arm bleeding apace

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: So, set him here a while, where is more air,
How cheer you sir, alack he doth begin
To change his colour, where is mistress Shore?
Gone to her closet for a precious balm,
The same (She said) King Edward used himself.
Alack I fear he'll die before she come.
Ran quickly for some rosa-solis, faint not sir,
Be of good comfort, come good mistress Shore,
What have you there?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Stand by and give me leave.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Unhappy me to lodge him in my house.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I warrant you woman, be not so afraid,
If not this bloodstone hanged about his neck,
This balm will staunch it by the help of God:
Lift up his arm whilst I do bathe his wound,
The sign belike was here when he was hurt,
Or else some principal and chief vein is pierced.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: However sure the surgeon was a knave,
That looked no better to him at the first.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Blame him not mistress Blage, the best of them
In such a case as this, may been to seek.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Now God be blessed, see the crimson blood,
That was precipitate, and falling down
Into his arm, retires into his face,
How fare you sir? how do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O wherefore have you waked me from my sleep?
And broke the quiet slumber I was in,
Methought I sat in such a pleasant place,
So full of all delight as never eye
Beheld, nor heart of man could comprehend,
if you had let me go I felt no pain,
But being now revoked my grief renews.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Give him some rosa-solis mistress Blage,
And that will like wise animate the sprites,
And send alacrity unto the heart,
That hath been struggling with the pangs of death.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Here sir drink this, you need not fear it sir,
It is no hurt, see I will be your taster,
Then drink I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Now fellows raise his body from the chair
And gently let him walk a turn or two.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Good sooth mistress Shore, I did not think till now
You had been such a cunning skilled physician.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: O mistress Blage, though I must needs confess,
It would have been more welcome to my soul,
If I had died and been removed at last,
From the confused troubles of this world,
Whereof I have sustained no mean weight,
Than lingering here be made a packhorse still
Of torments, in comparison of which
Death is but as the pricking of a thorn,
Yet I do thank you for your taken pains,
And would to God I could requite your love.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Sir I did you little good, what was done
Ascribe the benefit and praise thereof
Unto this gentlewoman, kind mistress Shore,
Who next to God preserved your feeble life.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: How? Mistress Shore, good friends let go your hold,
My strength is now sufficient of itself.
O is it she that still prolongs my woes?
Was it ordained not only at the first,
She should be my destruction, but now twice,
When gracious destinies had brought about,
To end this weary pilgrimage of mine,
Must she and none but she prevent that good,
And stop my entrance to eternal bliss?
O lasting plague, o endless corrosive,
It now repents me double that I scaped,
Since life's made death, and life's author hate.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir take my counsel and sit down again,
It is not good to be so bold of foot,
Upon the sudden till you have more strength.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Mistress I thank you, and I care not much
If I be ruled by you.
O God that she should pity me unknown,
That knowing me by her was overthrown,
Or ignorantly she should regard this smart,
That heretofore spared not to stab my heart.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By your leave mistress Blague, I am somewhat bold,
Is there not a gentleman within your house,
Called m. flood, came hither hurt last night?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Is his name flood, I knew it not till now,
But here he is, and well recovered,
Thanks to this gentlewoman mistress Shore.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Pardon me mistress Shore, I saw you not,
And trust me I am sorry at the heart,
So good a creature as yourself hath been,
Should be so vilely dealt with as you are,
I promise you the world laments your case.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: How means you sir? I understand you not?
Lament my case, for what? for Edward's death?
I know that I have lost a gracious friend,
But that is not to be remedied now.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No mistress Shore, it is for Richard's hate,
That too much envies your prosperity.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I know he loves me not and for that cause,
I have withdrawn me wholly from the court.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You have not seen the proclamation then?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: The proclamation? no, what proclamation?

sp.speaker: Bra
sp.l: O mistress Shore, the King in every street
Of London, and in every borough town,
throughout this land hath publicly proclaimed,
On pain of death that none shall harbour you,
Or give you food or clothes to keep you warm,
But having first done shameful penance here,
You shall be then thrust forth the city gates,
Into the naked cold forsaken field,
I fable not, I would to God I did,
See, here's the manner of it put in print,
'Tis to be sold in every stationer's shop,
Besides a number of them clapped on posts.
Where people crowding as they read your fall,
Some murmur, and some sigh, but most of them,
Have their relenting eyes even big with tears.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: God's will be done, I know my sin is great,
And he that is omnipotent and just,
Cannot but must reward me heavily.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It grieves me mistress Shore, it was my chance,
To be the first reporter of this news.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Let it not grieve, I must have heard of it,
And now as good, as at another time.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I pray ye mistress Blage have care of flood,
And what his charge is I will see you paid,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Farewell to all that still shall be my song,
Let men impose upon me ne'er such wrong,
And this extremity shall seem the less,
In that I have a friend to lean unto,
Sweet mistress Blage, there were upon the earth,
No comfort left for miserable Jane,
But that I do presume upon your love,
I know though tyrant Richard had set down,
A greater penalty than is proclaimed,
Which cannot well be thought, yet in your house,
I should have succour and relief beside.

sp.speaker: Bla
sp.l: What, and so I should be a traitor, should I?
Is that the care you have of me and mine?
I thank you truly, no there's no such matter,
I love you well, but love myself better:
As long as you were held a true subject,
I made account of you accordingly,
But being otherwise, I do reject you,
And will not cherish my King's enemy:
You know the danger of the proclamation:
I would to God you would depart my house.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: When was it ever e'en Jane Shore was false
Either unto her country, or her King?
And therefore 'tis not well good mistress Blage,
That you upbraid me with a traitor's name.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Ay, but you have been a wicked liver,
And now you see what 'tis to be unchaste,
You should have kept you with your honest husband:
'Twas never other like but that such filthiness,
Would have a foul and detestable end.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Time was that you did tell me otherwise,
And studied how to set a gloss on that
Which now you say is ugly and deformed.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I told you then as then the time did serve,
And more indeed to try your disposition,
Than any way to encourage you to sin:
But when I say you were ambitious,
And saintly stood on terms of modesty,
I left you to your own arbiterment:
Can you deny it was not so? how say you?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: We will not mistress Blage dispute of that,
But now in charity and womanhood,
Let me find favour if it be but this,
That in some barn or stable I may shroud.
Till otherwise I be provided for.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I pray you do not urge me mistress Shore.
I will not have my house endangered so.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O you did promise I should never want,
And that your house was mine, and swore the same,
To keep your oath be then compassionate.

sp.speaker: Bla,
sp.l: So you did swear you would be true to shore,
But you were not so good as your word,
My oaths disherit which by the King's command.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Yet let me have those jewels and that money,
Which is within my trunks.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I know of none:
If there be any, I'll be so bold,
As keep it for your diet and your man's,
It is no little charge I have been at,
To feed your dainty tooth, since you came hither,
Beside houseroom, I am sure is somewhat worth.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Ah Jane I cannot choose but pity thee,
Here's the first step to thy deep misery.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O that my grave had then been made my house,
When either first I went unto the court,
Or from the court returned unto this place.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How now, what are you? it had been manners
You should have knocked before you had come in.

sp.speaker: 1. Ap.
sp.l: We are the Bishop's parators my friend,
And mistress Shore our errand is to you.
This day it is commanded by the King,
You must be stripped out of your rich attire,
And in a white sheet go from temple bar,
Until you come to Algate, bore footed,
Your hair about your ears, and in your hand,
A burning taper, therefore go with us.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Even when and whither you will, and would to God,
The King as soon could rid my soul of sin,
As he may stripped my body of these rags.

sp.speaker: 2. Ap.
sp.l: That would be soon enough, but come away,
And mistress Blage you'll hardly answer it,
When it is known we found her in your house.

sp.speaker: 1. Ap.
sp.l: It seems you do not fear to harbour her.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I harbour her? out on her strumpet quean,
She pressed upon me where I would or no:
I'll see her hanged ere I will harbour her.
So now her jewels and her gold is mine,
And I am made at least four thousand pound,
Wealthier by this match than I was before:
And what can be objected for the same,
That once I loved her: well perhaps I did,
And women all are governed by the moon,
But now I am of another humour,
Which is you know a planet that will change.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Now m. sheriff of London do your office,
Attach this rebel to his majesty,
And having stripped her to her petticoat,
Turn her out a doors, with this condition,
That no man harbour her, that durst presume
To harbour that lewd courtesan Shore's wife,
Against the straight commandment of the King.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Away with her I say.
The while I'll seize upon her house and goods,
Which wholly are confiscate to the King.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: O what have I beheld, were I as young,
As when I came to London to be prentice,
This pageant were sufficient to instruct,
And teach me ever after to be wise.
First have I seen desert of wantonness,
And breach of wedlock: then of flattery,
Next of dissembilng love, and last of all,
The ruin of base catching avarice:
But poor Jane shore in that I loved thee once,
And was thy husband I must pity, thee,
The sparks of old affection long ago,
Raked up in ashes of displeasure kindle,
And in this furnace of adversity,
The world shall see a husband's loyalty.

div.stage:
Enter doctor Shaw pensively reading on his book, after
him follows the ghost of Friar Anselm, with a lighted torch.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Spuria vitulamina non agent radices altas.
Bastardly slips have always slender growth.
Ah Shaw, this was the cursed theme,
That at Paul's cross thou madest thy sermon of,
To prove the lawful issue of thy King,
Got out of wedlock, illegitimate.
Ah Duke of Gloster this didst thou procure.
Did Richard (Villain) no it was thy fault,
Thou wouldst be won to such a damned deed,
Which now to think on makes my soul to bleed.
Ah friar Anselm, sleep among the blessed,
Thy prophecy thus falsely did I wrest.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thou didst, and be thou damned therefore,
Ne'er come thy soul where blessedness abides,
Didst thou not know the letter G. was Gloster?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Anselm I did.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why then didst thou affirm,
That it was meant by George the Duke of Clarence
That honourable harmless gentleman,
Whose thoughts all innocent as any child,
Yet came through thee to such a luckless death.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I was enforced by the Duke of Gloster.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Enforced sayest thou? wouldst thou then be enforced,
Being a man of thy profession,
To sin so vilely, and with thine own mouth,
To damn thy soul? No thou wast not enforced,
But gain and hope of high promotion
Hired thee thereto, say was it so or no?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: It did, it did.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why then record in thy black hellish thoughts,
How many mischiefs have ensued hereon?
First wronged Clarence drowned in the tower,
Next, Edward's children murdered in the tower:
this day at Pomfret noble gentlemen,
Thrée the Queen's kindred, lose their harmless heads.
Thinkst thou that here this flood of mischief 〈◊〉
No villain, many are marked to the block,
And they the nearest, think them furthest off,
Even Buckingham, creator of that King,
Shall he to woe and wretched ending bring.
All this (Accursed man) hath come by thee,
And thy false wresting of my prophecy,
For England's good disclosed to thy trust,
And so it had been, hadst thou proved just.
But thou and every one that had a hand,
In that most woeful murder of the princes,
To fatal ends you are appointed all.
Here in thy study shalt thou starve thyself,
And from this hour not taste one bit of food,
The rest shall after follow on a row,
To all their deaths, vengeance will not be slow.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Where is m. doctor Shaw?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Here friend, what is thy will with me?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: K. Richard prays ye to come to him straight.
For he would be confessed.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I cannot come, I pray thee take that friar,
For he can do it better far than I.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: A friar m. doctor I see none.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Dost thou not? no, thy untainted soul
Cannot discern the horrors that I do.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Shaw go with him, and tell that tyrant Richard,
He hath but thrée years limited for life,
And then a shameful death takes hold on him,
That done, return, and in thy study end
Thy loathed life that didst us all offend,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: With all my heart, would it were ended now,
So it were done, I care not where nor how.

div.stage: Enter the two parators, with mistress Shoare in a white sheet, barefooted, with her hair about her ears, and in her hand a wax taper.

sp.speaker: 1. Par.
sp.l: Now mistress Shore, here our commission ends,
Put off your robe of shame, for this is Algate,
Whither it was appointed we should bring you,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: My robe of shame? O that so soul a name
Should be applied unto so fair a garment,
Which is no more to been condemned of shame,
Than snow of putrefaction is deserved,
To cover an infectious heap of dung,
My robe of shame, but not my shame put off,
For that sits branded on my forehead still,
And therefore in derision was I wrapped,
In this white sheet: and in derision bore
This burning taper, to express my folly,
That having light of reason to direct me,
Delighted yet in byways of dark error.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.l: Well mistress Shore, I hope you grudge not us,
We showed you all the favour poor men could.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: O God forbid: I know the Kings edict
Set you a work, and not your own desires.

sp.speaker: 1. Par.
sp.l: I truly mistress, and for our parts,
We could be well content 'twere otherwise,
But that the laws severe, and so we leave you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Farewell unto you both: and London too,
Farewell to thee, where first I was enticed,
That scandalizde thy dignity with shame,
But now thou hast returned me treble blame,
My tongue that gave consent enjoined to beg.
Mine eyes adjudged to hourly laments,
Mine arms for their embracings, catch the air,
And these quick nimble feet that were so ready
To step into a King's for bidden bed,
London thy flints have punished for their pride,
and thou hast drunk their blood for thy revenge,
What now avails to think what I have been,
Then welcome nakedness and poverty,
Welcome contempt, welcome you barren fields,
Welcome the lack of meat, and lack of friends,
And wretched Jane, according to thy state,
Sit here, sit here, and lower if might be:
All things that breath in their extremity,
Have some recourse of succour, thou hast none,
The child offended flies unto the mother,
The soldier struck, retires unto his captain,
The fish distressed, slides into the river,
Birds of the air do fly unto their dams,
And underneath their wings are quickly shrouded
Nay, beat the spaniel, and his master moans him,
But I have neither where to shroud myself,
Nor any one to make my moan unto,
Come patience then, and though my body pine,
Make then a banquet to refresh my soul,
Let hearts deep throbbing sighs be all my bread,
My drink salt tears, my guests repentant thoughts
That who so knew me, and doth see me now,
May shun by me the breach of wedlock's vow.

div.stage: Enter Brackenbury with a prayer book, and some relief in a cloth for mistress shore.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O God how full of dangers grows these till
And no assurance seen in any state,
No man can say that he is master now,
Of any thing is his, such is the tide
Of sharp disturbance running through the land,
I have given over my office in the tower,
Because I cannot brook their vile complots,
Nor smother such outrageous villainies:
But mistress Shore, to be so basely wronged,
and vildly used, that hath so well deserved,
It doth afflict me in the very soul,
She saved my kinsman, Harry Stranguidge life,
Therefore in duty am I bound to her,
To do what good I way, though law forbid,
See where she sits, God comfort thee good soul,
First take that to relieve thy body with,
And next receive this book, wherein is food,
Manna of heaven to refresh thy soul:
These holy meditations mistress Shore,
Will yield much comfort in this misery,
Whereon contemplate still, and never lin,
That God may be unmindful of thy sin.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Master lieutenant, in my heart I thank ye,
For this kind comfort to a wretched soul:
Welcome sweet prayer-book, food of my life,
The sovereign balm for my sick conscience:
Thou shalt be my soul's pleasure and delight,
To wipe my sins out of Jehovah's sight.
B. Do so good mistress Shore, now I must leave ye,
Because some other business calls me hence,
And God I pray regard your penitence.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Farewell sir Robert, and for this good to me,
The god of heaven be mindful still of thee.

div.stage: As she sits weeping and praying, enters at one door young m. air, and old Rufford at another.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: This way she went, and cannot be far off,
For but even now I met the officers,
That were attendant on her in her penance,
Yonder she sits, now then air show thyself,
Thankful to her, that sometime saved thy life,
When law had made thee subject to base death,
Give her thy purse, for here comes some lady,
Stand by a while, for fear thou be discovered.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: What mistress Shore, King Edward's concubine,
Set on a molehill, o disparagement.
A throne were fitter for your ladyship,
Fie will you flubber these fair cheeks with fears?
Or sit so solitary, where's all your servants?
Where is your gown of silk, your periwigs,
Your fine rebatoes, and your costly jewels,
What not so much as a shoe upon your foot,
Nay then I see the world goes hard with whores.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: The villain slave gibes at her misery.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Now whether is it better to be in court,
And there to beg a licence of the King,
For transportation of commodities,
Then here to sit forsaken as thou dost,
I think upon condition Edward lived,
And thou were still in favour as before,
Thou woulds not say that Rufford had deserved,
To have his ears rent for a worser suit,
Than licence to ship over corn and lead,
What not a word, faith wench I'll tell thee what,
If thou dost think thy old trade out of date,
Go learn to play the bawd another while.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.l: Inhumane wretch, why dost thou scorn her so,
And veer her grieved soul with bitter taunts,

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Because I will, she is a courtesan,
And one abhorred of the world for lust.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.l: If all thy faults were in thy forehead written,
Perhaps thou wouldst thyself appear no less,
But much more horrible than she doth now.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: You are no judge of mine sir.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Why nor thou of her.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: The world hath judged, and found her guilty,
And 'tis the King's command she be held odious.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: The King of heaven commandeth otherwise,
And if thou be not willing to relieve her,
Let it suffice thou seest her miserable,
and study not to amplify her grief.
sp.stage: Enter mistress Blage very poorly a-begging , with her basket and clap-dish.
sp.l: What other woeful spectacle comes here?
Mistress take that and spend it for my sake.

div.stage: When Rufford looks away, air throws his purse to mistress Shoare.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O I am pinched with more than common want,
Where shall I find relief? Good gentleman,
Pity a wretched woman like to starve,
And I will pray for ye. One halfpenny
For Christ's sake, to comfort me withal.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: What mistress Blage, is't you? no marvel sure,
But you should be relieved, a halfpenny quotha?
I marry sir, and so be hanged myself,
Not I, this gentleman may if he please,
Get you to your companion mistress Shore,
And then there is a pair of queans well met,
Now I bethink me, I'll go to the King,
And tell him that some will relieve Shore's wife,
Except some officer there be appointed,
That carefully regards it be not so.
Thereof myself will I make offer to him,
Which questionless he cannot but accept,
So shall I still pursue Shore's wife with hate,
That scorned me in her high whore's estate.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Good gentleman bestow your charity,
One single halfpenny to help my need.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Not one, were I the master of a mint,
What? succour thee that didst betray thy friend?
See where she sits, whom thou didst scorn indeed,
And therefore rightly art thou scorned again:
Thou thoughtst to been riched with her goods,
But thou hast now lost both thy own and hers,
And for my part, knew it would save thy life,
thou shouldst not get so much as a crumb of bread
Pack counterfeit, pack a way dissembling drab.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O misery, but shall I stay to look
Her in her face, whom I so much have wronged?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes mistress Blage, I freely pardon you,
You have done me no wrong, come sit by me:
'Twas so in wealth, why not in poverty?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O willingly if you can brook her presence,
Whom you have greater reason to despise.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why woman, Ric hard that hath banished me,
And seeks my ruin (Causeless though it be)
Do I in heart pray for, and will do still,
Come thou and share wit h me what god hath sent,
A stranger gave it me, and part thereof
I do as freely now bestow on you.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I thank you mistress Shore, this courtesy
Renews the grief of my inconstancy.

div.stage: Enter master Shoare with relief for his wife.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Yonder she sits how like a withered tree,
That is in winter leaveless and bereft
Of lively sap, sits she poor abye soul,
How much unlike the woman is she now,
She was but yesterday: so short and brittle
Is this world's happiness: but who is that.
False mistress Blage? how canst thou brook her Jane?
I thou wast always mild and pitiful,
O hadst thou been as chaste, we had been blessed,
But now no more of that: she shall not starve,
So long as this, and such as this may serve,
Here mistress Shore, feed on these homely cates,
And there is wine to drink them down withal.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Good sir your name, that pities poor Ia Shore
That in my prayers I may remember you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: No matter for my name, I am a friend,
That loves you well, so farewell mistress Shore,
when that is spent, I vow to bring you more.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: God's blessing be your guide where ere you go,
Thus mistress Blage you see amidst our woe,
For all the world can do, God sends relief,
And will not yet we perish in our grief,
Come let us step into some secret place.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: 'Tis not amiss, if you be so content,
For here the fields too open and frequent.
Where undisturbed we may partake this grace.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: What is she gone so soon? alack poor Jane,
How I compassionate thy woeful case?
Whereas we lived together man and wife,
Oft on an humble stool by the fire side,
Sat she contented, whenas my high heat,
Would chid her for it. But what would she say
Husband we both must lower sit one day,
When I dare swear thee never dreamt of this,
But see good God what prophesying is.

div.stage: Enter Rufford and fog, with the counterfeit letters patents, Shoare stands aside.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: This is King Richard's hand, I know it well,
And this of thine is justly counterfeit,
As he himself would swear it were his own .

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: The King's hand 〈◊〉 more of that.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Why every letter, every little dash,
In all respects alike, how may I use,
My transportation of my cousin and hides,
Without the danger of forbidding law,
And so I would have done in Edward's days,
But that good mistress Shore did please to cross me,
But mark how now I will requite her for it.
I moved my suit, and plainly told the King,
Some would relieve her, if no man had charge,
To see severely to the contrary.
Forth with his grace appointed me the man,
And gave me officers to wait upon me,
Which will so countenance thy cunning work,
As I shall no way be suspected in it: how sayest thou fog?

sp.speaker: Fogge.
sp.l: It will do well indeed:
But good sir have a care in any case,
For else you know what barm may come thereon.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A care sayest thou? why man, I will not trust
My house, my strongest locks, nor any place,
But mine own bosom, there will I keep it still,
If I miscarry, so doth it with me.

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Are ye so cunning sir, I say no more,
Jane Shore or I may quittance you for this.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Well fog I have contented thee,
Thou mayst be gone, I must about my charge,
To see that none relieve Shore's wife with ought.
Come on good fellows, you that must attend,
King Richard's service under my command,
Your charge is to be very vigilant,
Over that strumpet whom they call Shore's wife:
If any traitor give her but a mite,
A draught of water, or a crust of bread,
Or any other food whate'er it be,
Lay hold on him, for it is present death,
By good King Richard's proclamation,
This is her haunt, here stand I sentinel,
Keep you unseen, and aid me when I call.

div.stage: Enter jockey and Jeffrey, with a bottle of ale, cheese, and halfpenny loaves, to play at bowls, mistress Shoare enters and sits where she was wont.

sp.speaker: Jock.
sp.p: Now must I under colour of playing at bowls, help till relieve my good masters, masters Shore. Come, Jeffrey, we will play five up for this bottle of ale, and yonder good pure woman shall keep the stakes, and this cheese shall be the master.

div.stage: They play still towards her, and jockey often breaks bread and cheese, and gives her, till Jeffrey being called away then he gives her all, and is apprehended.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Here is a villain, that will not relieve her,
But yet he'll lose he bowles, that way to help her,
Apprehend him fellows when I bid ye:
Although his mate be gone, he shall pay for it.
Take him, and let the beadles whip him well.

sp.speaker: Jock.
sp.p: Hear ye sir, shall they be whipped and hanged that give to the pure, than they shall be damn that take from the pure.

div.stage: Enter young air again, and Shoare stands aloof off.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: O yonder sits the sweet forsaken soul,
To whom for ever I stand deeply bound:
She saved my life, than air help to save hers.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Whither go ye sir?
You come to give this strumpet some relief.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.l: She did more good than ever thou canst do,
And if thou wilt not pity her thyself,
Give others leave, by duty bound thereto:
Here mistress Shore, take this, and would to God
It were so much as my poor heart could wish.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Who is it that thus pities my poor wife?
'Tis m. air, god's blessing on him for it.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Darest thou do so air?

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.l: Rufford I dare do more:
Here is my ring, it ways an ounce of gold,
And take my cloak to keep ye from the cold.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Thou art a traitor air.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.l: Rufford, thou art a villain so to call me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Lay hold on him, attach him officers.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.l: Rufford, I'll answer thine arrest with this.

div.stage: He draws his rapler, but is apprehended.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: All this contending sir will not avail,
This treason will be rated at thy life.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Life is too little for her sake that saved it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Is he a traitor sir, for doing good?
God save the King, a true heart means no ill.
I trust he hath reclaimed his sharp edict,
And will not that his poorest subject perish,
And so persuaded I myself will do,
That which both love and nature binds me to.
I cannot give her as she well deserves.
For she hath lost a greater benefit.
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 take that purse.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: He takte away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: You shall not sir, for I will answer it,
Before the King if you enforce it so.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: It must be so, you shall unto the King.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: You will be he will first repent the thing:
Come m. air, I'll bear ye company,
Which wise men doth say ease calamity,

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: If grief to speech free passage could afford,
Or 〈◊〉 woe I had a fitting word,
I might complain, or if my floods of tears,
Could move remorse of minds, or pierce dull ears,
Or wash away my cares, or cleanse my crime:
With words and tears I would be the time.
But it is bootless, why live I to see,
All those despised that do pity me.
Despised? alas, destroyed, and led to death,
That gave me alms here to prolong my breath.
Fair dames behold, let my example prove,
There is no love like to a husband's love.

div.stage: Enter King Richard, Lovell, Catesby, Rufford, Shoar, and air pinioned, and led betwixt two officers.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now tell us Rufford which of these it is,
that in the heat of his upheaved spleen,
Contemns our crown, disdains our dignity,
And arms himself against authority.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Both have offended my dread sovereign,
Though not alike, yet both faults capital,
These lines declare what, when, and where it was.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Which is that air?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: This young man my liege.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I thought it was some hot distempered blood,
That fired his giddy brain with business:
Is thy name air?

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This paper says so.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Perish may he that made that paper speak.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ha? Dost thou wish confusion unto us?
This paper is the organ of our power,
And shall pronounce thy condemnation,
We make it speak thy treasons to thy face,
And thy malicious tongue speaks treason still.
Relievest thou Shore's wife in contempt of us?

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: No, but her just desert,
She saved my life, which I had forfeited,
Whereby my goods and life she merited.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And thou shalt pay it in the self same place,
Where thou this man our officer, didst out face,
And scorndst us saying if we stood by,
Thou wouldst relieve her.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: I do not deny,
For want of food her breath was near expired,
I gave her means to buy it undesired,
And rather choose to die for charity,
Then live condemned of ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Your good devotion brings you to thegallows,
He hath his sentence, Rufford see him hanged.
Now sir your name?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Is it not written there?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here's Mathew flood.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: That is his name my lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Is thy name flood?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: So m. Rufford sates.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Flood and air? the elements conspire,
In air and water to confound our power:
Didst thou relieve that hateful wretch Shore's wife?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I did relieve that woeful wretch Shore's wife.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Thou seemst a man well stayed and temperate,
Durst thou infringe our proclamation?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I did not break it.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes, and added more,
That you would answer it before the King.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: And added more, you would repent the thing.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Who, I? his highness knows my innocence,
And ready service with my goods and life,
Answer thy treasons to his majesty.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What canst thou say flood why thou shouldst not die?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Nothing, for I am mortal and must die,
When my time comes, but that I thinks not yet,
Although (God knows) each hour I wish it were,
So full of dolour is my weary life:
Now say I this, that I do know the man,
Which doth abet that traitorous libeler,
Who did compose and spread that slanderous rhyme,
Which scandals you, and doth abuse the time.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What libeler? another Collingborne?
That wrote: the cat, the rat, and Lovell our dog,
Do rule all England under a hog.
Canst thou repeat it flood?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I think I can if you command me so.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: We do command thee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: In this sort it goes.
The crook baked boar the way hath found,
To root our roses from our ground,
both flower and bud will he confound,
Till King of beasts the swine be crowned:
And then the dog, the cat, and rat,
Shall in his trough feed and be fat.

sp.speaker: Finis
sp.p: Quoth m. fog, chief secretary and counsellor to m. Rufford.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: How sayest thou flood, doth Rufford foster this?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: He is a traitor if he do my lord.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: I foster it? dread lord I ask no grace,
If I be guilty of this libelling,
Vouchsafe me justice as you are my prince,
Against this traitor that accuseth me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What justice cravest thou? I will combat thee,
In sign whereof I do unbutton me,
And in my shirt my challenge will maintain,
Thou call'st me traitor, I will prove thee one,
Open thy bosom like me if thou darest?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I will not be so rude before his grace.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Thou wilt not open the pack of thy disgrace.
Because thy doublets stuffed with traitorous libels.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Catesby tear off the buttons from his breast.
What findst thou there?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Your highness' hand and seal,
For transportation of hides, corn and lead.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Traitor, did I sign that commission?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: O pardon me most royal King.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Pardon? to counterfeit my hand and seal?
Have I bestowed such love, such countenance?
Such trust on thee, and such authority,
To have my hand and signet counterfeit?
To carry corn the food of all the land,
And lead, which after might annoy the land,
And hides, whose leather must relieve the land,
To stranger's enemies unto the land:
Didst thou so nearly counterfeit my hand?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Not I my liege, but fog the attorney.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Away with him Lovell and Catesby, go,
Command the sheriffs of London presently,
To see him drawn, and hanged, and quartered,
Let them not drink before they see him dead.
Hast you again.

div.stage: Lovell and Catesby lead out Rufford.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Well flood thou art my death,
I might have lived t'have seen thee lose thy head.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Thou hast but justice for thy cruelty,
Against the guiltless souls in misery,
I ask no favour if I merit death.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Crau'st thou no favour? than I tell thee flood,
Thou art a traitor breaking our edict,
By succouring that traitorous quean Shore's wife.
And thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: If I have broke the law.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: If traitor? didst thou not give her thy purse?
And doest thou not maintain the deed?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I do, if it be death to the relenting heart,
Of a kind husband, wronged by a King,
To pity his poor weak seduced wife,
Whom all the world must suffer by command,
To pine and perish for the want of food:
If it be treason for her husband then,
In the dear bowels of his former love,
To bury his own wrong and her misdeed,
And give her meat whom he was wont to feed,
Than Shore must die, for flood is not my name,
Though once I took it to conceal my shame,
Pity permits not injured Shore pass by,
And see his once loud wife with famine die.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Lovell and Catesby, this is Shore indeed,

sp.speaker: Shore,
sp.l: We confess that thou hast privilege,
And art excepted in our proclamation,
Because thou art her husband whom it concerns,
and thou mayst lawfully relieve thy wife,
Upon condition thou forgive her fault,
Take her again, and use her as before,
Hazard new horns, how saist thou, wilt thou Shore?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: If any but your grace should so upbraid,
Such rude reproach should roughly be repaid.
Suppose for treason that she lay condemned,
Might I not seed her till her hour of death,
And yet myself no traitor for it?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thou mightst.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And why not now (Oh pardon me dread lord)
When she hath had both punishment and shame
Sufficient, since a King did cause her blame,
May I not give her food to save her life,
Yet never take and use her as my wife?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Except thou take her home again to thee,
Thou art a stranger, and it shall not be,
For if thou do, expect what doth belong.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I never can forget so great a wrong.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then never feed her whom thou canst not love.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My charity doth that compassion move.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Move us no more, Lovell let air be hanged,
Just in the place where he relieved Shore's wife:
Shore hath his pardon for this first offence.
The name of husband pleads his innocence,
Away with them: Catesby come you with us?

div.stage: Jockey is led to whipping over the stage, speaking some words, but of no importance. Then is young air brought forth to execution, with the sheriff and officers, mistress Shoare weeping, and m. Shoare standing by.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Good mistress Shore, grieve me not with your tears,
But let me go in quiet to mine end.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Alas poor soul,
Was never innocent thus put to death.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.l: The Moors my joy, that I am innocent,
My death is the less grievous, I am so.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ah m. air the time hath been ere now,
When I have knelt to Edward on my knees,
And begged for him, that now doth make me beg.
I have given him, when he hath begged of me,
Though he forbids to give me when I beg,
I have ere now relieved him and his,
Though he and his deny relief to me:
Had I been envious then, as Richard now,
I had not starved, nor Edward's sons been murdered,
Nor Richard lived to put you now to death.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: The more Jane is thy virtue and his sin.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Come sir dispatch.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Dispatch say you? dispatch you may it call,
He cannot stay when death dispatcheth all.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Lord, is my sin so horrible and grievous,
That I should now become a murderer?
I have saved the life of many a man condemned,
But never was the death of man before.
That any man thus for my sake should die,
Afflicts me more than all my misery.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.l: Jane be content,
I am as much indebted unto thee,
As unto nature, I owed thee a life,
When it was forfeit unto death by law,
Thou begot it of the King and gavest it me:
This house of flesh wherein this soul doth dwell,
Is thine, and thou art landlady of it,
And this poor life a tenant but at pleasure,
It never came to pay the rent till now,
But hath run in arrearage all this while,
And now for very shame comes to discharge it,
When death distrains for what is but thy due,
I had not ought thee so much as I do,
But by thy only mercy to preserve it,
until I lose it for my charity.
Thou givest me more than ever I can pay,
Then do thy pleasure executioner,
And now farewell kind virtuous mistress Shore,
In heaven we'll meet again, in earth no more.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell, thou for thy alms dost die.
And I must end here starved in misery,
In life my friend, in death I'll not forsake thee,
Thou goest to heaven, I hope to overtake thee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: O world what art thou? man, even from his birth
Finds nothing else but misery on earth,
Thou never (World) scornedst me so much before,
But I (Vain world) do hate thee ten times more.
I am glad I feel approaching death so nigh,
World thou hatest me, I thee vain world defy.
I pray ye yet good master officers,
Do but this kindness to poor wretched souls,
As let us have the burial of our friend,
It is but so much labour saved for you.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: There take his body, bury it where you will,
So it be quickly done out of the way.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What's he that begs the burial of my friend,
And hath so oftentimes relieved me?
Ah gentle sir, to comfort my sad woe,
Let me that good kind man of mercy know.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Ah Jane, now there is none but thou and I
Look on me well, knowest thou thy ma. Shore?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My husband? then break and live no more.

div.stage: She swounds, and he supports her in his arms.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Ah my dear Jane, comfort thy heavy soul,
Go not away so soon, a little stay,
A little, little while, that thou and I,
Like man and wife may here together die,

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: How can I look upon my husband's face,
that shamed myself, and wrought his deep disgrace▪

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Jane be content, our woes are now alike,
With one self rod thou seest God doth us strike,
If for thy 〈◊〉, I'll pray to heaven for thee,
And if for mine, do thou as much for me.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Ah Shore, is't possible thou canst forgive me?

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Yes Jane, I doc.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I cannot hope thou wilt:
My faults so great that I cannot expect it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I'faith I do, as freely from my soul,
As at God's hands I hope to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Then God reward thee, for we now must part,
I feel cold death doth seize upon my heart.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: And he is come to me, here he lies,
I feel him ready to close up mine eyes,
Lend me thy hand to bury this our friend,
And then we both will hasten to our end.

div.stage: Here they put the body of young air into a coffin, and then he fits down on the one side of it, and she on the other.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.l: Sit thou there, here I my place will have,
Give me thy hand, thus we embrace our grave,
Ah Jane, he that the depth of woe will see,
Let him but now behold our misery:
But be content, this is the best of all,
Lower than now we are, we cannot fall.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Ah, I am faint, how happy aire art thou,
Not feeling that which doth afflict us now?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: O happy grave, to us this comfort giving,
Here lies two living dead, here one dead living,
Here for his sake, lo this we do for thee,
Thou lookest for one, and art possessed of thrée.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O dying marriage, o, sweet married death
Thou grave which only shouldst part faithful friends,
Bringst us together, and dost join our hands,
O living death, even in this dying life,
yet ere I go, once Mathew kiss thy wife.

div.stage: He kisseth her, and she dies.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Ah my sweet Jane, farewell, farewell poor soul,
Now tyrant Richard do the worst thou canst,
She doth defy thee, o unconstant world,
Here lies a true anatomy of thee,
A King had all my joy, that her enjoyed,
And by a King again she was destroyed:
All ages of my kingly woes shall tell,
Once more inconstant world farewell, farewell.

div.stage: Enter sir Robert Brackenbury, with two or three of his servants.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sirs if the King, or else the Duke of Buckingham
Do send for me, I will attend them straight,
But what are these here openly lie dead,
O God, the one is mistress Shore, and this is flood,
That was my man: the third is master air,
Who suffered death for his relieving her,
They shall not thus lie in the open way,
Lend me your hands, and heavy hearts withal,
At mine own charge lie give them burial.

div.stage: Enter King Richard crowned, Buckingham, air of Warwick, Lovell, Catesby, fog, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Most noble lords, since it hath pleased you,
Beyond our expectation on yeur bounties,
T'impale my temples with the diadem.
How far my quiet thoughts have ever been,
From this great 〈◊〉 〈◊〉,
Heaven best can witness: I am your King,
Long may I be so, to deserve your love,
But I will be a servant to you all,
Pray God my broken sleeps may give you rest.
But only that my blood doth challenge it,
Being your lawful prince by true succession,
I could have wished, with all my heart I could,
This majesty had sitten on the brow
Of any other: so much do I affect a private life,
To spend my dates in contemplation.
But since that heaven and you will have it so,
I take the crown as meekly at your hands,
As free and pure from an ambitious thought,
As any new born babe. Thus must thou Richard
Seem as a saint to men in outward show, aside.
Being a very devil in thy heart:
Thus must thou cover all thy villainies,
And keep them close from overlookers eyes.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: My sovereign by the general consent
Of all the lords and commons of the land,
I tender to your royal majesty,
This princely lady, the lady Anne of Warwick
Judged the only worthiest of your love,
To be your highness bride, fair England's Queen

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: My royal princely cousin Buckingham,
I see you strive to bless me more and more,
Your bounty is so large and ample to me,
You overflow my spirits with your great love,
I willingly accept this virtuous Princess,
And crown her angel beauty with my love.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Then as the hand of your high parliament,
I give her here unto your majesty.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lord Lovell I as heartily receive her,
Welcome fair Queen.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: And from the lords and commons of your land
I give the free and voluntary oath,
Of their allegiance to your majesty.
As to their sovereign and liege lord and lady,
Richard the third, and beauteous Anne his Queen,
The true and lawful King and Queen of England.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I do accept it Catesby, and return,
Exchange of mutual and party love.
Now fog too, that in your traitorous libels,
Besides the counterfeiting of our hand and seal
For Rufford, though so great a fault deserved
To suffer death, as he already hath,
Going about to slubber our renown,
And wound us with reproach and infamy,
Yet fog that thou thyself mayst plainly see,
How far I am from seeking sharp revenge,
Fog I forgive thee, and withal we do,
Repeal our heavy sentence 'gainst Shore's wife,
Restoring all her goods, for we intend,
With all the world now to be perfect friends.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Why my good lord, you knew she's dead already.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: True Catesby, else I ne'er had spoke such words,
Alas I see our kindness comes too late,
For Catesby tells me she is dead already.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I my good lord, so is her husband too.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Would they had lived, to see our friendly change,
But Catesby say, where died Shore and his wife?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Where air was hanged for giving her relief,
There both of them round circling his cold grave,
And arm in arm departed from this life:
The people for the love they bear to her,
And her kind husband, pitying his wrongs,
For ever after mean to call the ditch,
Shore's ditch, as in the memory of them,
Their bodies in the friar's minorites,
Are in one grave interred all together,
But mistress Blage for ingratitude,
To mistress Shore, lies dead unburied,
And no one will afford her burial.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But mistress Blage she shall have burial too,
What now we must be friends, indeed we must,
And now my lords, I give you all to know,
in memory of our eternal love,
I do ordain an order of the bath,
Twelve knights in number of that royal sort,
Which order with all princely ceremonies,
Shall be observed in all royal pomp,
As Edward's our forefather of the barter,
Which feast ourself, and our beloved Queen,
Will presently solemnize in our person.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Now am I bold to put your grace in mind
Of my long suit, and partly your own promise,
The Earl of Hereford's lands.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Cousin we'll better think on that here after.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: My pains my lord hath not deserved delay.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Will you appoint our time: than you shall stay,
For this hot hastiness sir you shall stay,
Moon us no more you were best.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: I Richard, is it come to this?
In my first suit of all, dost thou deny me?
Break thine own word, and turn me off so slightly,
Richard thou hadst as good have damned thy soul,
As basely thus to deal with Buckingham:
Richard I'll sit upon thy crumped shoulder:
I'faith I will, if heaven will give me leave,
And Harry Richmond, this hand alone,
Shall fetch thee home, and seat thee in his throne.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What is he gone in heat, why farewell be,
He is displeased, let him be pleased again,
We have no time to think on angry men:
Come my sweet Queen, let us go solemnize,
Our knighthood's order in most royal wise.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
